13291223: The South African government has agreed to establish a task team to address the issue of "corrective rape" and violence against lesbian women. The decision comes after an online petition gained over 170,000 signatures from 163 countries. The task team will include representatives from the judiciary, police, and social development department, as well as the gay community. Its objectives are to develop a legislative intervention plan, a public awareness strategy, and LGBTI-sensitive shelters. The move is seen as a significant step towards addressing the issue of violence against lesbian women in South Africa.  ### End of Response.  ### Summary: The South African government has agreed to establish a task team to address the issue of "corrective rape" and violence against lesbian women.  ### End of Summary.  ### End of Text.  ### End of Document.  ### End of File.  ### End of Record.  ### End of Entry.  ### End of Log.  ### End of File.  ### End of Document.  ### End of Text.  ### End of Record.  ### End of Entry.  ### End of Log.  ### End of File.  ### End of Document.  ### End of Text.  ### End of Record.  ### End of Entry.  ### End of Log.  ### End of File.  ### End of Document.  ### End of Text.  ### End of Record.  ### End of Entry.  ### End of Log.  ### End of File.  ### End of Document.  ### End of Text.  ### End of Record.  ### End of Entry.  ### End of Log.  ### End of File.  ### End of Document.  ### End of Text.  ### End of Record.  ### End of Entry.  ### End of Log.  ### End of File.  ### End of Document.  ### End of Text.  ### End of Record.  ### End of Entry
13890581: The UK government has announced a three-year funding package for the Cornish Language Partnership, ensuring the survival of the critically endangered language, with long-term support expected to come from Cornwall.
14958201: Manchester City secured a 2-0 win over Everton at Goodison Park, with Mario Balotelli and James Milner scoring the goals. Balotelli broke the deadlock in the 67th minute with a measured finish from the edge of the area, and Milner sealed the win with a slide-rule finish in the 89th minute. Everton struggled to create chances throughout the match, with City dominating possession and creating the better opportunities. The win moves City up to second place in the Premier League table, while Everton remain in 15th place.

20836172: A 20-year-old woman, Veronica Alverez, was killed in a road accident in Streatham High Road, London. She was on her way to work when a grey Audi collided with a bus stop, causing extensive damage. The driver of the Audi fled the scene. The victim's family has been left devastated by her death. The police are investigating the incident and are looking to speak to the driver of the Audi, Nathan Davis. The 51-year-old man injured at the bus stop remains in a critical condition in hospital. The condition of the 29-year-old driver of the Volkswagen is now stable.
20936833: The government's welfare cap bill has been met with opposition from some MPs, with the former education minister, Nicky Morgan, saying she would oppose the bill "with a heavy heart" due to its potential to create a divide between the working and non-working poor. The bill aims to cap welfare benefits at £23,000 per year for a single person and £26,000 for a couple. The government claims the measure will help to get more people in work and fewer out of work, but critics argue it will make society less generous and less able to co-operate. An impact assessment suggests single parents will be most affected, losing £5 a week or £250 over three years. The majority of working age households in receipt of state support are likely to be an average of £3 a week worse off.  was replaced as an education minister in last autumn's government reshuffle, said she would oppose the bill "with a heavy heart" because it was "disingenuous" to try to "find someone to blame for our own woes". "A fissure already exists between the working and non-working poor," she told MPs. "Hammering on that fault line with the language of 'shirkers and strivers' will have long-term impacts on public attitudes, on attitudes of one neighbour against another. "It will make society less generous, less sympathetic, less able to co-operate." However, Lib Dem deputy leader Simon Hughes told the House: "It's difficult but the government has got the right and I believe, after this parliament, it will be vindicated by getting more people in work and fewer out of work." David Cameron's official spokesman said: "The prime minister's view is that the welfare system has to be brought back under control. The measures that the government has been taking, ever since the government came to power, have been designed to that end." 29347771: Cricket Scotland's chief executive, Roddy Smith, has announced his departure after nearly a decade in the role. Smith has overseen significant growth and success for the organisation, including winning global qualifying events, playing in world cups, and running a fully professional national team. The recruitment process for his successor will begin, with the aim of having a replacement in place early in the new year. Smith will leave Cricket Scotland in good health, with a growing game and a number of newly-appointed quality staff. He will hand over to his successor an organisation well-placed to succeed in the future.
30358490: A man in his 20s suffered a head injury and suspected multiple fractures in a car crash on the A127 in Essex, and was airlifted to hospital for further treatment.
30816523: Mr Mosley, son of fascist leader Sir Oswald Mosley, won £60,000 after a judge ruled there was no substance to the allegation that there had been a Nazi theme to the sex party and found that his privacy had been breached. Google is being sued for refusing to remove images of the private sexual activity from its search engines. Google claims it is not the publisher of the private information and that Mr Mosley no longer has a reasonable expectation of privacy in relation to the images. The hearing is due to conclude on Thursday.
30844962: The European Commission had doubts over the Amazon deal with Luxembourg, including whether the country properly looked into Amazon's "transfer pricing" proposals and whether the proposed tax regime was in line with market conditions. 31723471: Manor Marussia F1 team has been saved by a new investment from businessman Stephen Fitzpatrick and former Sainsbury's boss Justin King. The team has been rebranded as Manor and has a new car, a modified version of the 2014 model, which must pass F1's mandatory crash tests before the season-opening Australian Grand Prix. Will Stevens has been announced as one of the team's drivers, with a second driver to be announced soon. The team's new business leadership is confident they will be competitive at the highest level.
32159602: The final minutes of Flight 4U 9525 were marked by a sudden and unexplained descent. The plane began its descent at 10:31, and by 10:39, it had crashed into a mountain near Seyne-les-Alpes. The cause of the descent is still unknown. Andreas Lubitz was the co-pilot of the flight. He was 27 years old and had been flying for Germanwings for about a year. He had been experiencing depression and had been treated for it. He had also been experiencing anxiety and had been taking medication for it. On the day of the crash, Lubitz had been acting strangely, and his behavior had been noticed by other pilots. He had been seen crying and had been overheard talking to himself. Despite these warning signs, Lubitz was able to take control of the plane and crash it into the mountain. The crash killed all 150 people on board. The cause of the crash is still under investigation.
33578778: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras was forced to sign a bailout agreement after being given a choice between execution and capitulation. He has announced a cabinet reshuffle, sacking ministers who voted against the reforms, but will still preside over ministers who have doubts about the programme. Greece must pass further reforms next week to secure the bailout. The process is expected to take four weeks. Banks will reopen on Monday with a weekly withdrawal limit of €420. A €7bn bridging loan from an EU-wide emergency fund has been approved.
33609927: The inquiry will investigate child sexual abuse in various institutions, including religious organisations, and aims to ensure that abusers are held accountable and victims receive justice. The inquiry will also examine the response of institutions to allegations of abuse and identify any systemic failures. The survivors of child sexual abuse hope that the inquiry will be truly independent and help ensure that abusers are not protected by their own congregations or religious leaders. The inquiry will investigate institutions such as local authorities, the police, schools, hospitals, and charities, among others. The full details of the inquiry will be broadcast on Radio 4's The Report on Thursday, 23 July.
34303109: Cuba all set for Pope Francis. The Pope is expected to focus on "the hopes and concerns" of the Cuban people, rather than publicly criticizing the government's human rights record. He will celebrate Mass in Revolution Square and visit the cathedral in Holguin. Nearly 1,000 journalists are expected to cover the visit. The Pope's trip will later take him to the US.
34352262: The Scottish National Party (SNP) government has been accused of making false claims about the NHS's performance, particularly regarding delayed discharge. Official statistics show that over 4,700 patients have been delayed more than six weeks since 2012, and nearly 400 in the past two months alone. The SNP government has been criticized for making claims about meeting targets when in reality thousands of patients have waited in hospital beds. Patients and staff do not benefit from bogus claims about NHS performance, and the government should correct the record and take action to address the issue. The Scottish government has introduced new targets, including an ambition for patients to be delayed for no more than 72 hours.
34540833: Glasgow Warriors lost to Dragons 24-17 in a game that could have gone either way. Glasgow's workrate and desire were excellent, but their errors ultimately cost them the game. The final score was 24-17 in favor of the Dragons.

34615665: Hurricane Patricia, a Category 5 storm, hit mainland Mexico, the first of its magnitude since 1959.
34944735: The blue colouration in tarantulas has evolved independently multiple times, with different mechanisms producing the same shade of blue. This suggests that the colour has an important visual signalling function, but it is unclear what this function is. It may be related to camouflage, warning potential predators, or even communication with other tarantulas. Further research is needed to determine the purpose of this unique colouration.
34988915: A British DJ, Mr. Fox, is on trial for alleged sexual misconduct with three young fans. He denies all allegations, claiming he never asked for consent and didn't understand the women's reactions. He admits to being alone with the women but claims it was innocent and not sexual. The trial continues.
35232142: The Scottish Borders has been hit by severe flooding, with many homes and businesses affected. Residents are calling for more support and a faster response to the crisis. The Labour Party's deputy Scottish leader Alex Rowley has visited the area and backed calls for immediate action to protect vulnerable areas. A flood alert remains in place across the Borders.
35360841: The Welsh government is introducing new measures to streamline the system and cut fraud in the transport sector, following concerns over rejected claims and suspended guidelines.
35550407: Life expectancy in England has improved, with 65-year-old men expected to live for a further 16.9 years and women a further 19.3 years. However, one quarter of areas in England have seen a decrease in life expectancy at age 65. The report highlights the importance of improving health in mid-life to achieve a good quality of life in later years. There is an urgent need to find out why improvements have stalled in many parts of England. In Scotland, life expectancy continues to improve, with 65-year-old men expected to live for a further 17.4 years and women a further 19.7 years. There are also wide variations across the country.
35890902: Wireless mice from several major companies, including HP, Lenovo, Amazon, and Dell, are vulnerable to hacking attacks that allow an attacker to send fake mouse clicks to a computer, effectively controlling the device. The attack can be carried out using a $20 device and a few lines of code, and can be done from a distance of up to 180m. The vulnerability is due to the fact that the signals sent by the mice are not encrypted, making it possible for an attacker to spoof the signals and take control of the device. Updates to the firmware of some of the vulnerable mice are being made available, but many of the insecure mice cannot be updated.
35932467: Demoitie, a Belgian cyclist, died after being hit by a car while riding in a breakaway group. The incident is under investigation. The UCI and CPA have issued statements, with the CPA asking what can be done to improve safety. Rowe, a professional cyclist, believes that the sport will not change in response to the incident. Another Belgian cyclist, Myngheer, died in hospital after suffering a heart attack during a race.
35951548:
There were three minutes at the end of the first session with no cars on the circuit, and the end of the second session was a similar damp squib.
Only one car - Nico Hulkenberg's Force India - was out on the track with six minutes to go. The two Williams cars did go out in the final three minutes but were already through to Q3 and so nothing was at stake.
The teams are meeting with Todt and F1 commercial boss Bernie Ecclestone on Sunday at noon local time to decide on what to do with qualifying for the rest of the season.
Todt said he was "optimistic" they would be able to reach unanimous agreement on a change.
"We should listen to the people watching on TV," Rosberg said. "If they are still unhappy, which I am sure they will be, we should change it."
Red Bull's Daniel Ricciardo was fifth on the grid, ahead of the Williams cars of Valtteri Bottas and Felipe Massa and Force India's Nico Hulkenberg.
Ricciardo's team-mate Daniil Kvyat was eliminated during the second session - way below the team's expectation - and the Renault of Brit Jolyon Palmer only managed 19th fastest.
German Mercedes protege Pascal Wehrlein managed an excellent 16th in the Manor car.

The Royal Ulster Agricultural Society's (RUAS) Balmoral Show is taking place at Balmoral Park in Lisburn, County Antrim. The event features local produce, livestock, and family fun activities. It coincides with Northern Ireland's Year of Food and Drink and showcases the best of local food and drink. The show includes an "edible garden", livestock displays, horse riding and show jumping, and awards for breeders and handlers. It also features family fun activities such as falconry displays and a balloon artist. The event is being covered live on social media by BBC News NI.  ### Related Questions

The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has left the decision to individual sports governing bodies, but the IPC has taken a stricter stance. Russia has up to 21 days to appeal against the decision. The UK has been ordered by the European Court of Justice (ECJ) to improve water quality in the Loughor Estuary in Wales. The court found the UK had failed to comply with EU clean water laws, citing spills from Welsh Water's discharges as a major contributor to the deterioration of water quality. The UK has been given until 2020 to improve the situation. Welsh Water is investing in a £113m project to reduce spills and improve water quality. The UK Government has said all sites in England included in the judgement now comply with the directive and plans are in place elsewhere across the UK to deliver compliance by 2020 at the latest.  godwit and shelduck
The local cockling industry has also been hit but Welsh Water insisted this was not due to their discharges.
It is investing in a Â£113m project to reduce the number of spills.
RainScape involves reducing the amount of water that reaches the sewers through planting green spaces on streets and roofs to absorb rain and building channels to capture surface water.
The UK argued the improvements would mean it could comply with EU clean water laws by 2020.
However, the ECJ - which rules on disputes involving EU legislation - found the UK had acted "too late" and was failing in its obligations.
Judges ruled spills contributed to the deterioration of water quality in the Loughor Estuary.
A Welsh Government spokesman said: "We will continue to work with Natural Resources Wales and Dwr Cymru on a Â£113m programme to reduce the number of spills, improve water quality and reduce the risk of local flooding by 2020."
Welsh Water added: "We have met the legal permits for water quality in the Loughor estuary and are aware of ever increasing environmental standards and the need to manage long-term challenges, such as climate change, in a truly sustainable away."

40260829: The Bulford Kiwi and the Messines Ridge model were recently excavated and protected by Historic England to preserve their historical significance. The Bulford Kiwi was cut into the chalk by New Zealand soldiers to mark their presence in England, while the Messines Ridge model commemorates the planning and victory of the war. The sites are important reminders of New Zealand's valour and connections with the UK.
